comments.commentBody: You are all talking about crisps, right?

Yep, I too, had no idea how "Wise" related to POTATO CHIP, and I didn't know ONI so I had to rely on the surrounding fill.  However, one of the reasons I love doing NYT crosswords is that sometimes (a lot of times) I learn something new and enjoy doing so.  One final thought, if that's supposed to resemble a cookie, I won't be the one eating it!

Interesting that this time it's the east that gets the clue, after all the references to restaurants in California and Canada.  We're getting to get all these regional foods without the hassle of traveling!
Fun puzzle, fun theme, I, like Mac, am not getting Wise One? / Potato Chip...
You have to wonder about the Koch brothers: so much effort to make more money when they'll probably be dead in 10 years or so. Foolish men. Dangerous men.
Bad men!
They've trained many to continue their work.

If Republicans take control of the Senate, their current unwillingness to work with Democrats will zoom to a new zenith. Their blockade of nominees to fill critical vacancies will stretch to the stratosphere. The Koch Brothers will get that shiny new tax cut for billionaires they've been wanting. And two years later, when government is underfunded due to Republican tax cuts, under-chaired due to Republican filibusters of nomiees, and more partisan than ever due to Republican intransigence, Republicans will say that the reason government is in such a shambles is the leadership of President Obama.

I'd tell you which chapters of their playbook it's from, but I had to burn it to keep warm on a cold October night. I might not have had to do it, but Republicans blocking jobs bills and safety net spending meant I needed to save money on my gas bill.

Did you even read the paper you just quoted? It says the exact opposite of what you think it says. Here is an excerpt. Pay special attention to the last sentence:

If symptomless Ebola carriage posed a significant risk of infection, evidence of sporadic cases of haemorrhagic fever associated with, but not directly linked to, major outbreaks of Ebola infection should be identifiable by standard epidemiological techniques. Unfortunately, social and political conditions in central Africa seriously impede contact tracing.3 However, within these limitations, transmission of Ebola has been observed to occur only after close personal contact with affected patients or by exposure to infected body fluids or organs.6 Every outbreak of Ebola to date has been contained by the institution of standard infection-control measures: effective body disposal, barrier nursing, destruction or sterilisation of contaminated equipment, and the appropriate use of gloves, masks, and gowns.7 This degree of containment would be virtually impossible if symptom-free carriers posed a significant threat of infection.

You really think Republicans would spend money for this? The military are paid for their time, civilians are not. The over reaction to one death is astonishing. 30,000 dead from guns, thousands from flu, tens of thousands from auto accidents, the sky is falling.

Today Chuck Hagel and the Joint Chefs ordered a 21 day quarantine for all US military personnel returning from West Africa. It seems reasonable that doctors and nurses who are in close contact with patients in the infectious stage of the disease should be quarantined for 21 days before going to uninfected countries.
President Obama, who said he supports the military quarantine but would not apply it to civilians, needs to get a better grasp of the situation. This is the only opportunity the US will have to prevent the spread of Ebola here and he must get it right the first time and quickly.
One thing Obama could do is to guarantee generous payments to nurses and doctors who volunteer to treat the epidemic in Africa and to include payment for a 21 day quarantine period. He should also require travellers to the US who have been in infected areas to undergo a 21 day quarantine either in the US or abroad before entering the US.
Finally, (and this is the elephant in the room that no one has addressed)_ the federal government should give large payments to doctors and nurses who volunteer to treat Edola patients in the US on condition that these cafregivers agree to live under quarantine while they are in direct contact with symptomatic patients and for 21 days afterward.
These measures are harsh, but this is our only chance to prevent the spread of Ebola out of West Africa. We cannot afford tomiss this opportunity to prevent th espread of the disease to the US.

It seems to me states should have the legal right for imposing quarantine action (apparently they do ), and if they do not have that now, they should act to acquire that right. Whether they apply it appropriately in varying circumstances is of course another matter and the courts can decide. As a layman, I'm not going to second guess the wisdom of their action.

It doesn't have to be seen as a contradiction. Our military is sending our people there; it is their assigned duty, as it will be their subsequent assigned duty to go to Italy. So with respect to being in the situation of Hickox, when we are in the military on duty we are not in a position to object that our freedom of movement is unjustly being restrained.

Nothing in their duties in places like Liberia should have them exposed to people with Ebola, but of course, what might happen? There are such people there and we, our military leaders who have taken the responsibility to send them there with their having no choice, have added responsibilities for them.

They are not medically trained people. In this situation let medical people watch over them. When they would return, depending upon their home duty assignments, they could be living in dorms or barracks, eating in mess halls, and so further would not be in positions to isolate or not according to their circumstances.

Even furthermore, having returned from Liberia, they themselves wold be at risk of being shunned, avoided, or isolated by others. By placing them in Italy during the subsequent 21 day period, they are protected from this problem.

Finally, who will complain about being in Italy?

Remember that the 1st Ebola patient in Dallas "vomited wildly" in the parking lot outside the apartment building, BEFORE he went to the hospital -- & the next Ebola case in the U.S. might vomit on a crowded subway, or on a plane during a long flight, etc. --  potentially infecting others -- before being put into isolation at a hospital.  FYI, 13% of Ebola patients do not get a fever before diagnosis -- so one might not realize when she has become contagious.  And the CDC website says that even just a cough or a sneeze could pass on the virus, if a droplet of the infected person's saliva lands on someone (or on a surface that gets touched by someone -- and the virus can survive on dry surfaces, like a doorknob, for many hours).  Bear in mind that Dr. Spencer said that he does NOT know HOW he caught it -- he said that he had followed the proper protocols for wearing protective gear in West Africa -- but somehow he still got infected.  There is no guarantee that an infected person's symptom would wait to start until they got home -- instead their (e.g.) fever could start when they are out in public -- which means that they could become contagious and potentially infect someone else when they are out in a crowded public venue.  Like Ms. Hickox, Dr. Spencer felt fine for many days after he returned -- but then it hit.  In light of all that, yes, quarantines are prudent.  Ebola is a terribly lethal virus.  When the stakes are high, caution is warranted.

If I had been working with Ebola patients who were severely ill—which I'm not sure Ms. Hickox was—I'd quarantine myself for 21 days on return to North America. So I support Maine's quarantine rules. That said, it's perfectly her right to challenge her confinement via a petition for writ of habeas corpus. That's what we have courts for . . . to decide these things. I have no complaints about a court challenge, although I wouldn't bring one, and in fact I support her right to seek a writ of habeas corpus.

Also, I believe the state should pay either her daily salary, if her employer won't, or imputed rent while she is confined. The state generally bears the cost of involuntary confinement, e.g., we don't charge prisoners or mental patients for their housing, with some rare exceptions. People quarantined against their will should also be lodged at state expense, even if they're at home.

The standard being set for the military is different from the standard for civilians for several reasons.

(1) Civilian HC workers are volunteers; the military are not -- this is their job. There is more discretion about how civilians are followed.

(2) The military are converging on West Africa from different postings all over the world. It is much more efficient -- and safer for them -- to monitor them together . . . and just in case there's a problem, to keep them together before allowing them to be posted out again.

President Obama said that Americans don't live on fear? Ha! We are whipped into a frenzy of fear about a new topic about every 6 months. It begins to look like a political ploy. It's amazing all the supposed threats to life and limb that simply pass you by if you don't watch news on TV and don't read the news. Sadly, I do read the news.

How many people have contracted Ebola in the US? How many people have died? (1). Do we not think that the far superior quality of our medical system and public health in the US will make it far less likely that Ebola could spread here, than in Africa? Is there any evidence that anyone is contagious after they, like Ms. Hickox, have tested negative for Ebola twice and are not running a fever? Do we want medical professionals to be discouraged from going to Africa to help with the devastation that is happening there (note again: it's not happening here).

Finally, is it not disturbing to see the near-unanimous near-hysteria that has been created in the populace concerning this issue? It used to be hard to imagine how people could get together in groups, string up a so-called witch, and cry "stone her". Now I see how easily that could happen.

A 21-day quarantine is not that big a deal -- if it's really medically necessary. But if it's being imposed based not on good science, and if it's a huge over-reaction (1 person dead, about 5 cases of Ebola), then it sets a terrible precedent for government overreach and authoritarianism.

Your post, which draws attention to the fact that the current outbreak is actually allowing scientists and researchers to study how the virus behaves in crowded urban environments (your post suggests that we are still waiting to see if people out on the street, as opposed to health care workers, can catch it) suggests that in a sense what is going on right now is an active scientific experiment! Maybe so many are calling for a quarantine not out of hysteria or irrationality, but out of a knee-jerk reaction to being subject to calculations of risk by the authorities (just as companies calculate acceptable liability).  Nobody likes to be "objectified" in this way.

A NY Times story today that said some of the medical staff had requested to stay at the hospital rather than returning home. Sadly the bulk of the article deals with shunning. It was however, interesting to note the number of medical staffers who had concerns about whether they could unwittingly spread the virus. This would seem to fly in the face of the often repeated comments that there is no science to back up quarantines for symptomatic medical staff. Apparently there are some healthcare workers who believe differently.

http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/30/nyregion/bellevue-workers-worn-out-fro...

Simple rules by fascists with simple minds are not necessarily the cure all you might be deluded into believing they are.  If you accept the logic of the argument that getting trained health care workers to West Africa to fight this scourge to extinction is the top priority, then why provide a penalty without any scientific basis for those doing this work?  So far the only person in the US to die of Ebola, died because they were turned away from the hospital (Texas Presby). You and others would do this nation a great service if you treated our doctors and volunteers with respect and science rather than fear and hocus pocus political posturing.

correction: Dr Spencer quarantined himself the moment his temperature exceeded 100 degrees - his only initial "symptom". And there's no evidence he infected anyone prior to quarantine. You are twisting facts to suit your own interpretation.

A physical anthropology prof told my class one day: "There are no capital "T" truths in biology; there are only little "t" truths, and those are only true until someone proves them false." That was his definition of science, and I think it a brilliant one.
She is not a threat to the health of the many.  That's the point.  There is no evidence at all to suggest that she can make anyone sick when she has no symptoms at all.
So is Dr. Buetler  also implying that the health workers who are currently in contact with an EVT patient in the United States be quarantined during treatment?
It is not one or the other,  we have to do both: commit massive resources to west africa and take reasonable precaution so the disease doesn't spread here.
If you can't handle 3 weeks of quarantine how can you handle Ebola-stricken west Africa?

I think the point that people may be discouraged from volunteering to help is significant because as long as there is ebola in Africa, there is a risk that there will be an infection that spreads here. If people want to be safe, the best thing to do may be to help stop the epidemic in Africa.

The problem has escalated with the doctor in NY that got ill many days after he returned home from West Africa.  The reports that he was sick and still going on the subway and  going around town when he did become ill has scared the public.  The public does not trust that the volunteer healthcare works will follow the self monitoring guidelines.  So as a result, people feel safer with stricter guidelines, hence all the fear.  To make matters worse, no one seems to believe most of the politicians and/or doctors.

She was trained by CDC as an Epidemic Intelligence Service Officer and graduated the 2012 class. It is a two year program. I'm certain part of that program is putting out the scripted story about infectious events.

If you don't think smoky back room tactics are involved in her media blitz of the last few days, ask yourself why her connections to CDC have been removed from her on-line profiles including LinkedIn.

Yes, you're being unfair because how is she different from the hundreds of other health professionals who have returned from fighting ebola over the past 40  years without being made a public example of by forcing them into an unnecessary quarantine?

And supposing public safety isn't being compromised? But a lot of hysterics who are rather short on common sense think you should be compromised?
I hope you're on the front lines of insisting that all children must be vaccinated because it actually is risky not to vaccinate.

The debate here is a simple one: to side with the idea that total individual freedoms is the most important thing in this case or that public safety is.  Being that anyone quarantined for 21 days is not being abused or physically harmed in any way, I say erring on the side of public safety is best.

Mark - The reason the United States interred the Japanese/American citizens during WWII was because the politicians were cowed by the public hysteria. In that sense this is exactly the same thing. In a civilized country public hysteria cannot be allowed to make policy.

Un-American,  yes.  Anti-democracy, yes.  Shameful and fearful, yes and yes.  Corrupt, oh yes.  Conspiratorial, yes.  Racist, undoubtedly.  These are desperate, conscience - free acts.  Un-American indeed.

"But given the margins that Democrats run up on Sundays, it is not hard to see why so many Republican election officials have sought to restrict early voting on Sundays."  Yes it's hard to see why. Voter suppression is despicable and un-American behavior.  It is disgusting that the Times and others describe and promote it as legitimate political conduct. We should shame this behavior into oblivion. Until we do, we are on the road to corrupt oligarchy, not vibrant democracy.

Mr. Sawyer contracted the disease in Africa and died in Africa.  Qev should have included him, but the fact is that his death had nothing to do with what has gone on here and doesn't alter the fact that there is no crisis in the US.
What hospital in the US treated Patrick Sawyer and on what date did he die in the US?

Okay Mr., he did not know about ONE American who died of Ebola which was contracted in Africa. Big Deal.
Do you know how many people die in America every day by;
Car Accident?
Gun Violence?
I rest my case.

"Ebola crisis"??

Five Americans are known to have contracted Ebola, worldwide; three while working in Ebola stricken countries and two who somehow broke safety protocol while working with a known Ebola sickened patient.

To date, all five of these citizens have been successfully cured of the virus and not a single American has died of the disease.

What "crisis"??
